Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Center for Hybrid Multicore Productivity Research (CHMPR) - Rutgers Site

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
As a research site of the NSF I/UCRC for Hybrid Multicore Productivity Research (CHMPR), the mission of the Rutgers Institute for Data Science, Learning, and Applications (I-DSLA) is to advance research and education in the area of Big data management and analytics. The multidisciplinary research program in collaboration with the industry partners, focuses on addressing research and development challenges in application domains that span healthcare; e-government and e-commerce; and community resilience and public safety. A key objective of this project is to integrate research and education by providing student opportunities to work on real world problems with industry partners. The emphasis on real problems is particularly suited to attracting individuals from diverse backgrounds, broadening participation in computer science and informatics research.


The research agenda of the Rutgers I-DSLA site is complementary and synergistic to that of CHMPR. The research projects at I-DSLA span several themes (data analytics, machine learning, data management, information security and privacy, social media, Web services, and semantic Web) and domains. In the healthcare domain, the multidisciplinary research program involves researchers from the Rutgers New Jersey Medical School Cancer Center, Rutgers I-DSLA, and Rutgers Center for Information Management, Integration, and Connectivity (CIMIC). The program leverages the complementary expertise of the team members to develop data analytics-based approaches that enables discovery of optimal treatment regimens and identification of patient and disease characteristics that permit responses to specific therapeutic combinations and modalities. In the e-government and e-commerce domains, the research work addresses fundamental problems related to secure information sharing, business process composition and management, and privacy-preserving data analysis. In the community resilience and public safety domain, the research work focuses on disaster management, critical infrastructure protection, and smart cities.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of the Center for Hybrid Multicore Productivity Research (CHMPR) led by UMBC was to advance the computational training of affiliated university students and faculty in the application and use of advances in multi-core computing technologies. The focus of Rutgers CHMPR Site spans several themes (data analytics, machine learning, data management, information security and privacy, social media, Web services, and semantic Web) and application domains (healthcare, e-commerce, e-government, digital libraries). Some of the major outcomes of the projects conducted at Rutgers CHMPR Site are as follows:

Intellectual merit outcomes

  • We have developed an integrated ontology-based reasoning framework for dynamic composition and management of emergency response processes. We validated its effectiveness by implementing FEMA Hazardous Materials Tabletop Exercise scenario and COVID-19 response scenario.
  • We analyzed independent risk factors (e.g., tumor variables, patient variables, race, ethnicity, treatment modalities, etc.) impacting survival and other cancer outcomes. We found that African American women with stage I-III estrogen receptors negative (ER-) and progesterone receptors negative (PR-) breast cancer had greater improvement in survival than Caucasians in 2001-2011 as compared to 1990-2000. This study clearly shows that more effort is needed to understand disparities based on tumor biology and to target these molecular differences.
  • We conducted a study designed to ascertain whether afferent vagal projections can be accessed non-invasively by transcutaneous electrical stimulation of the antero-lateral surface of the neck, which overlies the course of the vagus nerve. The results of this study showed that compared to baseline and control (SCM) stimulation, nVNS significantly activated primary vagal projections including: nucleus of the solitary tract (primary central relay of vagal afferents), parabrachial area, primary sensory cortex, and insula. Regions of the basal ganglia and frontal cortex were also significantly activated. Deactivations were found in the hippocampus, visual cortex, and spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • We developed automatic extraction of the job search features from job postings and resumes using clustering algorithms based on the multi-dimensional feature vector similarities. Our prototype  recommendation system has been deployed on Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud with DynamoDB as the backend database.
  • We developed a privacy-preserving approach to create synthetic data that can provide a first order approximation of utility and evaluated it in the context of data mining tasks such as regression, classification, and outlier detection. We also adapted the proposed approach to provide differential privacy guarantees and developed a new model of privacy that is appropriate for the identification of outliers.
  • We developed news categorization machine learning models that can group news articles into meaningful categories, identify redundant articles, and summarize them into succinct abstracts.  A Web application for News classification has been developed and delivered to the industry partner, which is being incorporated into their existing software platform.
  • Due to the lack of commercially viable of attribute-based access control (ABAC) systems, we developed an approach to translate an ABAC policy to the widely deployed role-based access control (RBAC) system.
  • We proposed an efficient incremental ABAC policy maintenance approach that does not require re-mining of ABAC policies whenever there is a change.

Broader impact outcomes

  • 5 PhD dissertations resulted from the research conducted during this project.
  • 9 Masters students? and 1 postdoctoral fellow?s projects are based on the work performed during this project.
  • Several refereed conference and journal publications resulted from the research and development work performed during this project.
  • Several spin-off funding resulted from the research and development work performed during this project.

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2021
Modified by: Vijayalakshmi Atluri
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The mission of the Center for Hybrid Multicore Productivity Research (CHMPR) led by UMBC was to advance the computational training of affiliated university students and faculty in the application and use of advances in multi-core computing technologies. The focus of Rutgers CHMPR Site spans several themes (data analytics, machine learning, data management, information security and privacy, social media, Web services, and semantic Web) and application domains (healthcare, e-commerce, e-government, digital libraries). Some of the major outcomes of the projects conducted at Rutgers CHMPR Site are as follows: Intellectual merit outcomes We have developed an integrated ontology-based reasoning framework for dynamic composition and management of emergency response processes. We validated its effectiveness by implementing FEMA Hazardous Materials Tabletop Exercise scenario and COVID-19 response scenario. We analyzed independent risk factors (e.g., tumor variables, patient variables, race, ethnicity, treatment modalities, etc.) impacting survival and other cancer outcomes. We found that African American women with stage I-III estrogen receptors negative (ER-) and progesterone receptors negative (PR-) breast cancer had greater improvement in survival than Caucasians in 2001-2011 as compared to 1990-2000. This study clearly shows that more effort is needed to understand disparities based on tumor biology and to target these molecular differences. We conducted a study designed to ascertain whether afferent vagal projections can be accessed non-invasively by transcutaneous electrical stimulation of the antero-lateral surface of the neck, which overlies the course of the vagus nerve. The results of this study showed that compared to baseline and control (SCM) stimulation, nVNS significantly activated primary vagal projections including: nucleus of the solitary tract (primary central relay of vagal afferents), parabrachial area, primary sensory cortex, and insula. Regions of the basal ganglia and frontal cortex were also significantly activated. Deactivations were found in the hippocampus, visual cortex, and spinal trigeminal nucleus. We developed automatic extraction of the job search features from job postings and resumes using clustering algorithms based on the multi-dimensional feature vector similarities. Our prototype recommendation system has been deployed on Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud with DynamoDB as the backend database. We developed a privacy-preserving approach to create synthetic data that can provide a first order approximation of utility and evaluated it in the context of data mining tasks such as regression, classification, and outlier detection. We also adapted the proposed approach to provide differential privacy guarantees and developed a new model of privacy that is appropriate for the identification of outliers. We developed news categorization machine learning models that can group news articles into meaningful categories, identify redundant articles, and summarize them into succinct abstracts. A Web application for News classification has been developed and delivered to the industry partner, which is being incorporated into their existing software platform. Due to the lack of commercially viable of attribute-based access control (ABAC) systems, we developed an approach to translate an ABAC policy to the widely deployed role-based access control (RBAC) system. We proposed an efficient incremental ABAC policy maintenance approach that does not require re-mining of ABAC policies whenever there is a change. Broader impact outcomes 5 PhD dissertations resulted from the research conducted during this project. 9 Masters students? and 1 postdoctoral fellow?s projects are based on the work performed during this project. Several refereed conference and journal publications resulted from the research and development work performed during this project. Several spin-off funding resulted from the research and development work performed during this project. Last Modified: 08/16/2021 Submitted by: Vijayalakshmi Atluri
